docs.lead_paragraph: For all that scientists have learned about influenza since the catastrophic pandemic of 1917-19, one thing has not changed: the predictably unpredictable nature of the viruses that cause it. The sudden detection of the new swine influenza virus, A(H1N1), occurred just as scientists were focusing wary eyes on behavioral changes observed in another virus, the A(H5N1) bird flu strain, in Egypt. Virologists have tracked the avian virus since its discovery in Hong Kong in 1997.

headline.main: Sound the Alarm? A Swine Flu Bind

docs.snippet: The viruses that cause flu are predictably unpredictable.

byline.original: By LAWRENCE K. ALTMAN, M.D.; Keith Bradsher contributed reporting from Hong Kong

docs.lead_paragraph: The Obama administration dispatched high-level officials from several agencies Monday to allay concerns about swine flu and to demonstrate that it was fully prepared to confront the outbreak even as the president said there was ''not a cause for alarm.'' Janet Napolitano, the secretary of homeland security, and Dr. Richard E. Besser, the acting director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, said the administration was prepared to respond to any further spread of the swine flu virus.

headline.main: Obama Seeks To Ease Fears On Swine Flu

docs.abstract: Obama administration dispatches high-level officials from several agencies to allay concerns about swine flu and to demonstrate its preparedness to confront outbreak; Pres Obama says there is no cause for alarm, even as Janet Napolitano, homeland security secretary, and Dr Richard E Besser, acting director of Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, say they expect outbreak to spread and are proceeding as if preparatory to full pandemic level; administration responds to first domestic emergency by building on concrete preparations made during Bush administration that won praise by health experts; aides to Obama are also mindful that political management of crisis, and of public expectations, can be as important as immediate response; swine flu outbreak is linked to 149 deaths in Mexico; number of confirmed cases in US grows to 45; photo; map (L)
docs.snippet: The Obama administration dispatched high-level officials from several agencies to demonstrate that it was fully prepared to confront the outbreak.

docs.lead_paragraph: How dangerous is the sudden outbreak of swine flu? What makes this virus different from previous flu viruses? Pam Belluck, a science reporter at The Times, answered readers' questions about swine flu and its implications for health, below.

headline.main: Readers' Questions: The Swine Flu Outbreak

docs.lead_paragraph: Travel health expert Dr. Mark Gendreau addresses questions about the current swine flu outbreak and air travel. Dr. Gendreau is senior staff physician and vice chair of emergency medicine at Lahey Clinic in Burlington, Mass., and assistant professor of emergency medicine at the Tufts School of Medicine in Boston. His special interests include health issues associated with commercial air travel, including transmission of infectious diseases.

headline.main: Is It Safe to Fly During the Swine Flu Outbreak?

docs.lead_paragraph: President Obama addressed the annual meeting of the National Academy of Sciences on Monday morning, stressing the commitment he made during his campaign to "restore science to its rightful place" in the policy arena.
